abstract: Miguel Helft discusses Google Buzz, artist Randy Sarafan makes new things with dead computers and the meaning of “e-cycling.”
snippet: Miguel Helft discusses Google Buzz, artist Randy Sarafan makes new things with dead computers and the meaning of “e-cycling.”
lead_paragraph: In this week’s Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein discusses Buzz from Google with Miguel Helft, the Times reporter who followed how Google’s foray into social networking fell afoul of privacy concerns and generated the wrong kind of buzz.

headline.main: Tech Talk Podcast: The Buzz on Buzz

abstract: Nathan Myhrvold’s mission and the activities of the company he heads, Intellectual Ventures, a secretive $5 billion investment firm that has scooped up 30,000 patents, inspire admiration and angst, The New York Times writes.
snippet: Nathan Myhrvold’s mission and the activities of the company he heads, Intellectual Ventures, a secretive $5 billion investment firm that has scooped up 30,000 patents, inspire admiration and angst, The New York Times writes.
lead_paragraph: Nathan Myhrvold wants to shake up the marketplace for ideas. His mission and the activities of the company he heads, Intellectual Ventures, a secretive $5 billion investment firm that has scooped up 30,000 patents, inspire admiration and angst, The New York Times’s Steve Lohr writes.

abstract: Microsoft and Yahoo have received clearance from regulators in Washington and Europe to proceed with a search partnership intended to challenge Google.
snippet: Microsoft and Yahoo have received clearance from regulators in Washington and Europe to proceed with a search partnership intended to challenge Google.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft and Yahoo have received clearance from regulators in Washington and Europe to proceed with a search partnership intended to challenge Google, The Associated Press reports.

headline.main: U.S and Europe Clear Microsoft-Yahoo Search Deal

abstract: Over the last 18 months, hackers have breached more than 2,500 private and government computers, Kodak isn’t happy with Apple and Research In Motion, and David Pogue reviews Google Buzz.
snippet: Over the last 18 months, hackers have breached more than 2,500 private and government computers, Kodak isn’t happy with Apple and Research In Motion, and David Pogue reviews Google Buzz.
lead_paragraph: Your morning roundup of technology news:

headline.main: Bits Scan: Thursday’s Tech News Roundup

abstract: The proposal to create the world’s largest digital library has put giants like Sony and Microsoft on opposite sides.
snippet: The proposal to create the world’s largest digital library has put giants like Sony and Microsoft on opposite sides.
lead_paragraph: The federal judge overseeing the proposed settlement of a class-action lawsuit filed against Google by groups representing authors and publishers heard from a handful of supporters and a parade of objectors to the deal at a hearing Thursday in Manhattan.

headline.main: Judge Hears Arguments on Google Book Settlement
headline.print_headline: Judge Hears Arguments on Google Book Settlement

abstract: In the annual Ad Blitz poll conducted by YouTube, owned by Google, the most votes from computer users went to the Super Bowl commercial for Doritos called “House Rules.”
snippet: In the annual Ad Blitz poll conducted by YouTube, owned by Google, the most votes from computer users went to the Super Bowl commercial for Doritos called “House Rules.”
lead_paragraph: Madison Avenue continues to pore over the results of the polls and surveys showing how consumers responded to the commercials that ran during Super Bowl XLIV on CBS on Feb. 7.

headline.main: Forget Those Games in Vancouver. We Haven’t Finished Analyzing the Super Bowl Ads.
